review_title: Great staff, great clients, great work culture
pros:
Great, GREAT manager. I am able to be flexible with my hours which is a MUST for my family. There are occasions where we have to go in at night (police involvement, mental health crisis, etc), but it's only happened about 4 times in my 2.5 years in the position.
We clock in for the time we are at work so we are fairly compensated. Many social work positions include the rotating nights/weekends in the salary. In this position it counts towards your weekly hours, so you either get overtime (hourly), comp time (salary), or can work less hours during the week if it's something that happens towards the beginning of the pay period.
The caseload is manageable, and the manager of my program takes great care to listen to his staff's needs
While the pay is bad, I do save money on childcare due to the flexibility of my hours, which is one of the reasons I've stayed
The only healthcare option offered is a High Deductible Health Plan (HDHP) which I do not like.
cons:
The pay is low for the area. Starting pay is below$20/hour with a Master's degree (40k a year). As a result there is a lot of turnover-people enjoy it as an entry level position but often move elsewhere.
After 2 years and a promotion with more responsibility, pay was increased to 50k, which is entry level pay for an MSW in Northern Virginia
Life insurance is covered at zero cost to you.

job_title: Direct Support Professional (DSP) in Arlington, VA
pros: pick your schedule, work as much or little as you want
cons: management deliberately tries to push employees out

job_title: Human Resources Director in Nokesville, VA
pros: Solid administrative backbone. Caring and passionate employees.
cons: Funding constrains ability to offer robust compensation and benefits packages.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Arlington, VA
pros: When there are outings for the consumers, you get to eat for free, you get to engage in the activity for free too. Watching some of the clients develop.
cons: Upper managment has no clue how hard the little people work. Most of the program managers are more business focused instead actually caring about the progress of the individuals. They report what they choose to report to their superiors as long as it makes them look good. The company charges the clients despicable fees to live in a room in a group home. You will not move up in rank unless you prove to the higher ups that you are business minded. Depending on what program you work, you can provide a million ideas and suggestions, but they will be ignored....or managers will present them as their own. Micromanaging from manager.

review_title: Making a difference in YOUR community!
pros: CR's mission is to provide quality care to individuals with intellectual/ developmental/ mental health diagnoses.  Through independent living skills and providing linkages to community resources, CR is helping people with disabilities live a more independent and dignified life!  There are ample career opportunities with different concentrations in the field, that can open other opportunities for growth and development.  CR has frequent job fairs, opening up career opportunities to all in the community!
cons: CR works within the guidelines of policy and procedures, federal and state regulations, etc hence the on-boarding process can range from 2-4 weeks to hire as background checks, references, and executive/state approvals must be received.

job_title: Direct Support Professional in Richmond, VA
pros:
Sometimes the job can be really fun, at least if you're in one of the programs, because you get to attend events and even travel with the individuals.  Plus, if you're looking for a job with meaning, this job has it.  You really do make a difference in someone's life here, and it can be very rewarding to see the fruits of your labor as goals are achieved in the long-run.  The dress code is pretty relaxed, too, as in, you can wear jeans to work if you're in the field. Overall, it's a great job for the right person.
There are many, many people at this company that are very passionate about their jobs and about the mission of the agency, and that's great to see, especially when this includes the executives in corporate.
cons:
Depending on the level of care you're providing, you might have to clean up poop or drool, deal with challenging behaviors, etc.  Sometimes working overnight without notice when someone calls out, not always predictable.  A lot of work with low pay and no scheduled breaks (the pay is comparable to or better than like positions with other companies, though, and low pay comes with this field),
It can be hard to move up.  You'll be passed over because you don't have the right experience and then be ignored by your supervisor/program manager/clinical director when you ask for help with acquiring the necessary.  At the same time, they really do believe in promoting from within, so for the right person, there might be a great opportunity.
They're very tight on budgets--but that comes with working for a non-profit.

review_title: Working at community residence is a learning experience
job_title: Direct Support Professional in Arlington, VA
pros: the best reason to work at community residences is the self fulfillment
cons: their really no challenges in working for community residences either you want to do this type or work or you don't

pros:
Overall I had a very positive experience with Community Residences.  Our department was very diverse and had a solid group of workers who all got along.  
-Being able to travel in the Northern Virginia area.
-Being on your own schedule and those of the Clients.
-Easy to follow documentation system (Credible)
-IT department was very good.
-Clients were the best part of the job.
cons:
-Had some difficulties with HR.
-Had a few co-workers who had more difficult case loads.
-Low Pay
